Claim: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Aajtak didn't telecast such news.
Label: False
html:
Claim: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.

Explanation:Aajtak didn't telecast such news.

https://aajtak.intoday.in/story/fact-check-aajtak-never-shows-amit-shah-suffering-with-corona-virus-1-1175196.html

Claim: Bat market and bat meat are being sold in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video taken in Indonesia (Manado)
Label: False
html:
Claim: Bat market and bat meat are being sold in Wuhan.

Explanation:Video taken in Indonesia (Manado)

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200130-intox-chine-soupe-chauve-souris-rumeur-origine-coronavirus?check=6

Claim: A positive case of the 2019 novel coronavirus was “confirmed” to be found in Cebu province.
Explaination: The Department of Health announced on Jan. 28 there remains to be no positive case of the 2019 nCoV in the country, only that there are 27 people under investigation for suspected infection.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: A positive case of the 2019 novel coronavirus was “confirmed” to be found in Cebu province.

Explanation:The Department of Health announced on Jan. 28 there remains to be no positive case of the 2019 nCoV in the country, only that there are 27 people under investigation for suspected infection.

https://verafiles.org/articles/vera-files-fact-check-fb-posts-mislead-claims-positive-novel

Claim: Hospital is caught using a dummy in pandemic footage.
Explaination: Footage was for training on how to use ventilators.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Hospital is caught using a dummy in pandemic footage.

Explanation:Footage was for training on how to use ventilators.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/fact-check-hospital-caught-red-handed-using-dummies-in-pandemic-footage.html

Claim: The new coronavirus contains HIV “insertions” and shows signs of being created in a lab.
Explaination: This stems from a poorly done study that was retracted. There is no evidence that the new virus was bioengineered, and every indication it came from an animal.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The new coronavirus contains HIV “insertions” and shows signs of being created in a lab.

Explanation:This stems from a poorly done study that was retracted. There is no evidence that the new virus was bioengineered, and every indication it came from an animal.

https://www.factcheck.org/2020/02/baseless-conspiracy-theories-claim-new-coronavirus-was-bioengineered/

Claim: A video shared thousands of times on Facebook claims to show police in Zimbabwe beating churchgoers because their place of worship refused to close to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Explaination: The claims are false; the video was filmed before the virus outbreak. It shows opposition supporters being dispersed after gathering to hear their leader.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video shared thousands of times on Facebook claims to show police in Zimbabwe beating churchgoers because their place of worship refused to close to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

Explanation:The claims are false; the video was filmed before the virus outbreak. It shows opposition supporters being dispersed after gathering to hear their leader.

https://factcheck.afp.com/video-shows-zimbabwe-police-beating-opposition-members-not-churchgoers-defying-virus-rules

Claim: The army is patrolling all the streets, towns and villages in Ireland.
Explaination: New and unprecedented measures have been introduced to help curb the spread of the coronavirus, but the post false describes that those rules actually are. Police are patrolling parts of the country, but not all of it, and there are no plans at present for the army to patrol the streets.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: The army is patrolling all the streets, towns and villages in Ireland.

Explanation:New and unprecedented measures have been introduced to help curb the spread of the coronavirus, but the post false describes that those rules actually are. Police are patrolling parts of the country, but not all of it, and there are no plans at present for the army to patrol the streets.

https://jrnl.ie/5061925

Claim: “COVID literally stands for Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.”
Explaination: COVID-19 is an abbreviation of “coronavirus disease 2019.” “CO” stands for “corona,” “VI” stands for “virus” and “D” stands for “disease.” The number 19 reflects the year the disease was identified — 2019.
Label: Pants on Fire!
html:
Claim: “COVID literally stands for Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.”

Explanation:COVID-19 is an abbreviation of “coronavirus disease 2019.” “CO” stands for “corona,” “VI” stands for “virus” and “D” stands for “disease.” The number 19 reflects the year the disease was identified — 2019.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/30/viral-image/covid-stands-coronavirus-disease-2019/

Claim: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.
Explaination: The viral post claims that the world has been using coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic on novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred is for cattle, it is neither related with humans, not with COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.

Explanation:The viral post claims that the world has been using coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic on novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred is for cattle, it is neither related with humans, not with COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-cattle-vaccine-not-related-to-covid-19-misleading-post-getting-viral/

Claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.
Label: PANTS ON FIRE
html:
Claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”

Explanation:The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/feb/29/blog-posting/hair-extensions-arent-source-2019-coronavirus/

Claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explaination: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.

Explanation:We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15307002

Claim: Footage purportedly showing a looting spree in Mexico prompted by panic over the novel coronavirus was aired on multiple Facebook live streams and viewed by tens of thousands of people during the week of 3/23/20. Posts sharing the streams claimed that the chaotic scene was happening in real-time.
Explaination: The claim is false; the streams showed old footage from a 2017 looting incident in Mexico that was being played on a loop.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Footage purportedly showing a looting spree in Mexico prompted by panic over the novel coronavirus was aired on multiple Facebook live streams and viewed by tens of thousands of people during the week of 3/23/20. Posts sharing the streams claimed that the chaotic scene was happening in real-time.

Explanation:The claim is false; the streams showed old footage from a 2017 looting incident in Mexico that was being played on a loop.

https://factcheck.afp.com/footage-looting-was-filmed-years-pandemic

Claim: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.
Explaination: Both images belong to different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second photo portrays two doctors who care for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.
Label: False
html:
Claim: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.

Explanation:Both images belong to different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second photo portrays two doctors who care for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.

https://spondeomedia.com/falso-muertos-por-coronavirus-y-medicos-en-zona-de-contagio/

Claim: If Florida banned alcohol sales due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Story came from a prank news generator.
Label: False
html:
Claim: If Florida banned alcohol sales due to coronavirus.

Explanation:Story came from a prank news generator.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/03/Fact-Check-Florida-Did-NOT-Ban-Alcohol-Sales-Beginning-Today.html

Claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.
Explaination: This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.

Explanation:This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.

https://factcheck.afp.com/false-posts-claim-covid-19-existed-2019-use-animal-vaccines-proof

Claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.

Explanation:A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.

https://pesacheck.org/false-there-are-no-confirmed-cases-of-novel-coronavirus-in-zanzibar-2c8e23a6a02e

Claim: The Health Minister in Ecuador quit her job because she was forced to lie about the statistics of COVID-19 related cases.
Explaination: Her reasons to resign the Health Minister are unknown.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The Health Minister in Ecuador quit her job because she was forced to lie about the statistics of COVID-19 related cases.

Explanation:Her reasons to resign the Health Minister are unknown.

http://www.ecuadorchequea.com/las-mentiras-sobre-el-covid-19-en-ecuador/?fbclid=IwAR1LPZVARe1YjPhq3jijxwuSjIPKxv_9Io6BRDHJ2Cx45oaFHlhnm2_y5ZI?check=2

Claim: This photo shows a Sri Lankan airline pilot who tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the local health authority told AFP the pilot is not pictured in the photo; the man wrongly identified in the posts denied the claim.
Label: False
html:
Claim: This photo shows a Sri Lankan airline pilot who tested positive for the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:The claim is false; the local health authority told AFP the pilot is not pictured in the photo; the man wrongly identified in the posts denied the claim.

https://factcheck.afp.com/photo-does-not-show-pilot-who-tested-positive-after-visiting-cricket-game-sri-lanka

Claim: Research by the Saint Luke’s Hospital of Kansas City found that consuming alcoholic beverages may reduce the risk of infection by coronavirus. Vodka was the most recommended drink.
Explaination: The hospital dismissed the claim as false. Further, the World Health Organization (WHO) does not recommend alcohol consumption to prevent the coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Research by the Saint Luke’s Hospital of Kansas City found that consuming alcoholic beverages may reduce the risk of infection by coronavirus. Vodka was the most recommended drink.

Explanation:The hospital dismissed the claim as false. Further, the World Health Organization (WHO) does not recommend alcohol consumption to prevent the coronavirus.

https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/fact-check/254434-alcoholic-drinks-reduce-coronavirus-risk

Claim: Video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: We tracked the girl's social media accounts, confirmed they were authentic. She claims the video was taken over the summer but wouldn't tell were. The setup and meal look like Palau traditional bat soup but we couldn't confirm.
Label: No evidence
html:
Claim: Video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.

Explanation:We tracked the girl's social media accounts, confirmed they were authentic. She claims the video was taken over the summer but wouldn't tell were. The setup and meal look like Palau traditional bat soup but we couldn't confirm.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200130-intox-chine-soupe-chauve-souris-rumeur-origine-coronavirus?check=1

Claim: President Donald Trump in the next 48 to 72 hours will impose a nationwide “mandatory quarantine.”
Explaination: The White House’s National Security Council addressed the claim in a statement on Twitter, saying: “Text message rumors of a national #quarantine are FAKE. There is no national lockdown.”
Label: False
html:
Claim: President Donald Trump in the next 48 to 72 hours will impose a nationwide “mandatory quarantine.”

Explanation:The White House’s National Security Council addressed the claim in a statement on Twitter, saying: “Text message rumors of a national #quarantine are FAKE. There is no national lockdown.”

https://www.factcheck.org/2020/03/false-claims-of-nationwide-lockdown-for-covid-19/

Claim: As the US government moved to approve a $2 trillion stimulus package to address the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, a short block of text outlining Canada’s alleged response to the outbreak flourished on social media.
Explaination: The claims about school closings and economic support are misleading; no province has officially closed schools through the end of the year, only individuals directly impacted by COVID-19 are eligible for financial aid, and mortgage relief is granted by banks on a case by case basis.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: As the US government moved to approve a $2 trillion stimulus package to address the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, a short block of text outlining Canada’s alleged response to the outbreak flourished on social media.

Explanation:The claims about school closings and economic support are misleading; no province has officially closed schools through the end of the year, only individuals directly impacted by COVID-19 are eligible for financial aid, and mortgage relief is granted by banks on a case by case basis.

https://factcheck.afp.com/us-social-media-users-mischaracterize-canadas-covid-19-aid-package

Claim: News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country.
Explaination: The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The Prime Minister did not make this statement.
Label: False
html:
Claim: News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country.

Explanation:The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The Prime Minister did not make this statement.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/no-pm-modi-has-not-announced-an-internet-shutdown-during-lockdown-7405

Claim: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against Coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon help fight against coronavirus. The viral post is fake.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against Coronavirus.

Explanation:There is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon help fight against coronavirus. The viral post is fake.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-no-evidence-to-prove-that-turmeric-and-lemon-help-fight-against-coronavirus/

Claim: For coronavirus cases “in the U.S. 38% of those hospitalized are under 35.”
Explaination: The CDC reported that between mid-February and mid-March, 20% of the hospitalizations for coronavirus were for patients age 20-44 and 18% were age 45-54.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: For coronavirus cases “in the U.S. 38% of those hospitalized are under 35.”

Explanation:The CDC reported that between mid-February and mid-March, 20% of the hospitalizations for coronavirus were for patients age 20-44 and 18% were age 45-54.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/20/marco-rubio/young-people-are-being-hospitalized-covid-19-too-l/

Claim: 14 University of Nairobi students have tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: An article by Times Live claiming that 14 students from the University of Nairobi are infected with coronavirus cites a non-existent news story by KTN News.
Label: False
html:
Claim: 14 University of Nairobi students have tested positive for COVID-19.

Explanation:An article by Times Live claiming that 14 students from the University of Nairobi are infected with coronavirus cites a non-existent news story by KTN News.

https://pesacheck.org/false-a-post-claiming-that-14-university-of-nairobi-students-are-infected-with-covid-19-is-a-hoax-7a0ddd3be2a8?source=rss----ab41f21aa9a9---4

Claim: A Chinese pirate movie called “Coronavirus” is sold in Mexico City.
Explaination: The video is actually a 2013 South Korean film called Gamgi.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A Chinese pirate movie called “Coronavirus” is sold in Mexico City.

Explanation:The video is actually a 2013 South Korean film called Gamgi.

https://spondeomedia.com/falso-pelicula-asiatica-sobre-el-coronavirus/

Claim: The novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) “will not last long” in the Philippines because of its warm climate.
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) has not said that temperature affects the spread of 2019-nCoV and they don't recommend exposure to heat as protection or a treatment for the virus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) “will not last long” in the Philippines because of its warm climate.

Explanation:The World Health Organization (WHO) has not said that temperature affects the spread of 2019-nCoV and they don't recommend exposure to heat as protection or a treatment for the virus.

https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/fact-check/250679-coronavirus-eliminated-high-temperatures

Claim: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
Explaination: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.

Explanation:The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/viral-audio-clip-coronavirus-not-dr-devi-shetty-1657486-2020-03-19

Claim: Inhaling the steam from boiled water with dissolved salt is an effective cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: As of Tuesday, March 31, there is still no cure approved to treat the novel coronavirus, but there are treatments approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that may help ease the symptoms. Inhaling salt water steam is not among them.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Inhaling the steam from boiled water with dissolved salt is an effective cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:As of Tuesday, March 31, there is still no cure approved to treat the novel coronavirus, but there are treatments approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that may help ease the symptoms. Inhaling salt water steam is not among them.

https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/fact-check/256475-salt-water-steam-cure-coronavirus

Claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
Explaination: The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust
Label: False
html:
Claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.

Explanation:The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust

https://jrnl.ie/5045982

Claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
Explaination: The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.
Label: False
html:
Claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.

Explanation:The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200312-coronavirus-attention-ces-intox-alimentent-theories-complot

Claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.
Explaination: Authorities denied those claims.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.

Explanation:Authorities denied those claims.

http://u.afp.com/34jH

Claim: Video claiming you can’t catch coronavirus.
Explaination: Anyone can be affected by the coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Video claiming you can’t catch coronavirus.

Explanation:Anyone can be affected by the coronavirus.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/fact-check-video-claiming-you-cannot-catch-coronavirus-is-not-true.html
